reviews: The book was well written but seemed to drag a bit at the beginning.I knew the basic story  of Michelle Obama’s upbringing so did not find the first half of the book too compelling!I was hoping to get more “behind the scenes” info on some of the struggles of the Obama Administration but she stuck mostly to just her life in the White House.

reviews: I love Michele snd learned so much about her and her husband. There was so much information and  her style is wonderful. The book did however seem too long and in need of some tightening in the middle especially. After the election things moved better. In the beginning I was absorbing so much , but then wanted it to move faster. It was comforting to know this great woman was insecure and conscious of her ability to grow and change without losing her essence and her soul. Her sense of humor makes her so real and someone you want to follow for her next chapters. I loved the story and her writing but gave it a 4 because it needed trimming.

reviews: Another reviewer accused Michelle Obama for being boring and boastful.  Not true!  Read Trump's interesting book "Art of the Deal" if you want boastful.  I find Michelle's book fascinating with some similarities to my life growing up in a small house full of cousins, uncles, aunts and women renters who worked at the bomber plant during WWII.  Merely mentioning that you went to Princeton and Harvard Law School is not boastful ... boasting not required!  I'm still reading ... can hardly put it down.  So far her book is equal to any written by or about Winston Churchill, the four Kennedy brothers, and many more.The Kindle version is excellently done.

reviews: This book is honest and candid.  Reading it feels so intimate.  It is as though you are having a one-on-one conversation with her.  She lets us see her as she is while she is always Becoming....I sat in the nose bleed section of a 25,000 seat arena for Mrs. Obama’s book tour.  With my daughters and 5 grandchildren, we were amazed that we all felt her presence, she is so dynamic - we felt that we were in the front row.  The experience was also very personal.She connects us all.  She connects WITH us all.

reviews: This was my second reading of this powerful story of a gracious woman. This second time around during a pandemic and the daily comments from an Administration that is so clearly living in another reality, I read so much more in the words before me.  Each example written of the wrongs, hurts,  injustices seemed to echo jn the daily news. I would encourage eveyone who has read this before to read it again...and for those who are still on the fence about reading this the first time, do not hesitate to read it and encourage others to do the same.

reviews: I'm reading Michelle Obama's book Becoming. It is a page-turner.Her writing is sensuous, lithe, intelligent, insightful, playful and straight from the heart.My kind of person.If you've thought about reading it, I urge you to do so.

reviews: Michelle Obama’s literary style invited me to get to know her. She shared her personal journey - struggles, successes, joys, anxieties, fears, and more  - in an accessible and interesting way. I felt a connection - this old, ordinary white woman with a younger, glamorous, anything but ordinary, African American woman. We are mothers, wives, learners, worriers, lovers, caretakers, risk takers - all of us. Her writing  invites women everywhere to focus on our commonalities. I couldn’t put it down.

reviews: On page 389 or so it hit me hard! This book was going to end! The fact of that saddened me more than I was prepared for. Throughout my reading this I felt lifted up, embraced by arms of hope and dignity. I couldn't wait to get home from work to continue, but felt the creeping in of sadness knowing, like all great stories, there is a formula that includes an end. Michelle Obama inspires more than any person I know of.  I will savor whatever the rest of her life becomes revealed, for her intellect, her grace, her compassion, her wit, and mostly her optimism foretell great things come!  I can only say thank you for being who you are!

reviews: A national treasure, a role model for young women, and a fierce foe of all the "unbecoming" racism that has ensued since the Obama presidency.  May we see her like again very, very soon.

reviews: Michelle’s background was close family support, high morals, and hard work - who had the right to criticize her??She held her opinions close until Trump came on the scene, then queried why he was feted when he openly boasted his lack of respect for women, treated them as sex objects.

reviews: I love that Michele reads her own book and she is a pro at it. It was like an intimate conversation with her. She sings a song at one point which made it more like a performance than a reading.  I could not stop listening.Michelle made their journey to the White House real and highlighted how improbable it was. It gives me hope that Obama was able to be elected to the highest office in spite of all the odds against him but I also I see that it's unlikely for lightning to strike twice.

reviews: I loved this book.  Mrs. Obama has proven in her writing something I already realized about her before, she is a true lady.  Someone who thinks about others, shows concern that everyone has a "voice" that deserves to be heard.  It doesn't matter what color your skin is, what your religion is or your economic place in the world.  All of us, men, women and children have the right to speak and love free.

reviews: I so enjoyed seeing Michelle "become"! She could not have done a better job of allowing the reader insight into her personal life but also politically. She validates a lot of my own ideas about how things actually happen in politics. While I have been disappointed, I will take a page from her book and remain positive that the spirit of America will eventually overcome the present movement of the country. I admire Michelle Obama for being the woman she is and I thank her for sharing her story so beautifully!

reviews: I found this "autobiography" a heartwarming and intimate look into the life of a person who should be much admired and copied for her dedication to enlightening and uplifting young women in today's world. The stories about her childhood and growing up on the south side of Chicago is very relatable to the way a lot of people were raised and living during those years. I would recommend this book to everyone.

reviews: Unlike many autobiographies of public figures, Michelle Obama's account is a compelling read because it is offered in such an intimate, authentic voice. She draws the reader into her confidences - not salacious revelations, but sensitive insights about the small but critical moments of life and the choices that lead us to become the people we are. It's a remarkable story - as Barack Obama would say, a uniquely American one. It draws the curtain back for readers to see aspects of our America many of us never lived, but recognize, and to see it with the honesty and compassion of Michelle Obama's vision.

reviews: What a hardworking and remarkably put together person! Everything in the book seemed so genuine, and really does demonstrate how she became the person she is.I think what I enjoyed reading the most was how her parents treated her and her brother growing up. That they talked to them like adults because they were raising adults, not babies. It’s excellent parental modeling as I too want my kids to learn to make educated decisions themselves.Reading about the constant desire to do well and the obvious respect she has towards her family, peers, and teachers was very inspirational. I’d highly recommend this book!

reviews: Amazing. Stupendous. Inspiring. I now have a new found love and appreciation for Mrs. Obama. It was extremely heartwarming reading about her humble beginnings, drive to be better, beating the odds, supporting Barack and ensuring that Malia and Sasha remained at the epicenter of her life.I appreciate knowing more about what goes into having your privacy stripped away when becoming the US president and First Lady. We see on tv what happens, but this is real from someone who experienced it first hand.I feel almost like I’m a friend of Michelle’s because she was so honest and down to earth. She shared such intimate things while all the while making me feel inspired.You rock, Michelle!

reviews: It makes you long for those times when the world respected us, when our president was a man of honor and decency, a true public servant. And it painfully contrasts with the Orange Monster who currently loots our country, pollutes our land, and alienates our real allies as he sides with dictators, and fills Washington with the swampiest creatures ever assembled. Oh how I miss the Obamas.

reviews: Imagine, if you will, that Ms. Obama sits down with you in your living room - in a comfortable chair, or on the couch. And tells you her story. Face to face. Openly. Honestly. Vulnerably. She shares her laughter with you, and her pain, and her anger. She shares herself with you. If you think you would like that, read this book. If you think you wouldn't like that, then I challenge you to read this book with an open mind and an open heart.  Because an open mind and an open heart is her gift to us.

reviews: I have always admired Michelle Obama, so it was a pleasure to hear her story from the early years to the present, how she lived various struggles, took hold of opportunities, and also learned how to care for the less fortunate, both at the community level and with specific individuals. My favorite part was hearing about the comings and goings once she was in the White House. The inside view. A person asked me, "But why the title BECOMING?" One possible response can be found early in the book--she did not feel good enough, seemed always to fall short. However, by the end, you might surmise that "becoming" means she is ready to take hold of the next challenge, always moving forward, and always caring to make a difference. Michelle Obama has heart, compassion, insight, and wisdom, and we were lucky to have her leadership for the years of her husband's presidency. I loved her book and wish her well.

reviews: This is an extremely well-written book that everyone should enjoy and learn from. Michelle Obama is a person to be admired, regardless of one's possible political partisanship. She writes honestly and easily about her life before meeting her future husband, her life with her husband, then their life (her part of it) with the entire country. I highly recommend the book to everyone.

reviews: Michelle Obama is, in her words, an ordinary person who lived an extraordinary 8 years in the White House. But her life is much more: an account of determination, grace and power of achievement both alone and in concert with many others who shared her goals and dreams. This book is a celebration of and a testament to her strength and intelligence and love under pressure. It is hopeful and inspirational and well worth reading twice.

reviews: Michelle is an excellent writer, passionate about her family and full of insights into the presidency of Barack Obama.  I have enjoyed every chapter.

reviews: Not sure what I expected, but I was pleasantly surprised by this book.  A south (west) side Chicago resident, it felt like home because of so many familiar things presented throughout the book.There was surprises along the way, with revelations sprinkled throughout!  I would recommend it.  It revealed personality, something I wasn't expecting.I actually listened to it.  Later going through the pictures.  I look forward to actually reading it, the old fashion way, soon.

reviews: Michelle Obama is a great story teller. The book is an easy read and at the same time very compelling. The book is really about an "ordinary" black girl who thanks to her parents and the support around her; has a well rounded upbringing and how as a young lawyer is ambitious and hard working like so many others. In many ways Barack Obama coming into her life makes Michelle go off her well planned path and into the unknown.....and the rest is history.Michelle is forthright about how as a black and as a woman she had to "work twice as hard to achieve half as much". What is amazing is Michelle's positive can do attitude to life. Obama is luck to have had a well grounded partner in his life.Definitely a book worth reading.

reviews: I wish I could have read this as a young woman starting out. I think I might have gone a different direction had I been able to benefit from Michelle’s experiences and how she handled herself.  It’s beautifully and intelligently written, easy to read, and compelling throughout. She satisfied my curiosity of what it’s like to live in the White House as the first family. The energy and fortitude required to be in such a public position is not for the feint of heart. I admire her ability to stand up for what she knew was right and get things done in spite of a sometimes critical, unforgiving, and uncooperative public. She’s amazing and has my utmost admiration.

reviews: After reading this book, I feel a renewed hope for who we are as a country and for the human spirit in general. Michelle Obama's story is a truly, uniquely American story of what we can become — together and individually — when we open our eyes and hearts. Beautifully written, sometimes amusing, often moving, it is the story of the optimism that shines through when we seek out the best in each other. Read this book, please.

reviews: This was a excellent book into who Michelle and Barack were before the world knew them. It was also a firsthand account of their journey to the White House. You imagine that it wasnt easy for either of them but you get a better sense of why Barack felt he needed to enter the Presidential race. Yet you also understand despite the unsurities Michelle she supported the man she loved.  I would definitely recommend you read this book about struggle, overcoming the obstacles and more importantly what it means to love and supportive of each other.

reviews: Love this lady and was so very interesting to hear what her life was like for the duration from campaigning to spending eight years in the white house.  Makes me ashamed of Americans to hear what she had to go through and the name calling and insults.  She's a very lovely lady and we should all be proud to have had her for First Lady.  Sure beats the one we've got now.

reviews: I have always admired the Obama's and I was so proud to be an American during Barak's presidency, so of course I wanted to learn more about former First Lady Michelle Obama and the struggles she faced. It was such an interesting and intimate read that lets you peek inside her struggles and triumphs.  I really enjoyed this book, it was deeply moving and uplifting.

reviews: I was on the Obama bandwagon from the start. I loved her writing, the background information, her unpretentious and everyday life. Beneath that boils a woman who is very smart, dedicated and capable.But I felt left out at the end the end. I am white and male and felt excluded, as if I was not part of her conversation. I understand fully why she was so interested in women's rights, especially black women's rights and appreciated that. I cheered to hear her say so strongly and clearly that they way to often get short shrift in our culture. I loved to hear her clear and articulate support of Barack, but I voted for him too. I felt a bit let down at the end of the book. I admire Michelle and Barack so much, especially now.

reviews: I love how Michelle Obama shares her stories of becoming who she is today, from childhood to the White House days. The every day stuff and the extraordinary. The overarching theme is one of hope for the future to be better. Her future, as she grew up and evolved, but then a hope for the future of everyone to be better. I also appreciated all the stories of hard work along the way. Clearly, nothing was given to Michelle. She worked hard at everything she did, including things she didn’t necessarily choose, like being First Lady. A thoroughly enjoyable read that left me inspired and hopeful once again in all that can be.

reviews: "Becoming" is an autobiography of Michelle Obama, from her own  childhood days through the 8 year presidency of her husband Barak.Obama. It gave me insight into the lives of Michelle and Barak, and an understanding of how they were able to do so much for America even tho many of their plans and wishes were thwarted by the Republican Senate. This book made me ache for the days of decency and hope we saw during "the Obama Era."  It is a wonderful read!

This book made me ache for the days of decency and hope we saw during "the Obama Era."  It is a wonderful read!

reviews: I always liked Mrs Obama as our First Lady. She was beautiful, graceful, and real in how she presented herself during her husband's Presidency. I don't enjoy reading autobiographies which typically I find dry and boring. Not so, Becoming!  I didn't want to put it down. Becoming is written in the  voice of your best friend sitting beside you and talking about her life.The most important gift I received  from reading Becoming is the wonderful story of two regular, good kids who wanted to make a difference in the lives of others. It is so easy to see how God lead both of them throughout their lives to be ready and capable when the time was right to lead American with wisdom and love. Thank you Mrs. Obama.

reviews: I followed the 44th family closely in the press, but this book gave me new insight into the lives of this president and First Lady. I am so proud that our country twice chose such a stellar president and that the package came with a most intelligent, striving, optimistic, and forward thinking Michelle Obama. She is not afraid to tell the story like it is and how it needs to be heard. I pity the person who doesn’t get the chance to read this book because it will help you learn how to be a better human being with love and hope for humanity and our country. Thank you, Mrs. Obama.

reviews: Michelle Obama has been my favorite First Lady in my lifetime (I was born when Truman was president).  Her memoir not only informed and uplifted me, but gave my spirit focus and hope.  Her start in Chicago was not poverty, but it certainly wasn't material wealth.  She acknowledges the family and friends who shaped her growing up were the reason for her strength and courage.  In sharing her story, I was truly impressed with her honesty; and her prose is excellent.  This goes on my list of best books of 2018.

reviews: I was very much looking forward to reading this autobiography, and it exceeded my anticipations. Brava Michelle Robinson Obama. Job well done on so many levels. I believe every young person, especially every young woman, should read this book. This is personable, believable and heart-warming. Mrs. Obama is articulate and succinct; her willingness to appear so transparent is courageous and inspiring. It makes me want to meet her in person, shake her hand, give her a hug, and thank her from the bottom of my heart.

reviews: I really enjoyed Michelle Obama's book, Becoming, because she spent a lot of time and effort reflecting on the many opportunities that have come her way. She has a unique perspective on what it means to be a "woman of color" in an influential role. She expresses a high degree of humility and takes seriously her opportunity to educate and inform others of her perspective. Before I read the book I respected Michelle, now I know more and my respect has grown. Definitely worth reading!

reviews: I loved hearing about Michelle's growing up years with her parents and brother Craig. When the narrative gets into politics, the only person who comes up short for Michelle is Donald Trump.  I know that the Obamas ran a very smooth campaign with harmonious relationships, but this degree of positivity stretches credibility. The interesting question this book raises is how much sacrifice is justified. Their daughters were still young and in need of parenting, but the presidency requires such security that normal is hardly possible. I wonder what the girls would say about the way they have grown up--that's the perspective that would be new.

reviews: I really like the Obamas so this book was a treat to read for me. Michelle's book is a pleasure to read. How she managed to maintain a family routine with all that she and Barack had going on is quite impressive.  I really admired how she related the core values she was raised with, the expectations as a black woman, and how seriously both they took their roles as leaders of the country and as the first black president and first lady. A great read.

reviews: The aspect I found most interesting in a book that had many such was Obama's level of self awareness:  she is able to turn her sharp intellect on herself and honestly present her foibles as well as her fortes.  She even makes clear when she is being careful about how she presents or discusses certain events and people, primarily from her years as First Lady.  The insights into the confined world of the White House can't be anything other than fascinating.....And she comes across as genuinely fond and appreciative of the massive staff that protected and served her family.  Well written in a graceful, easy manner--kind of like the person who wrote it herself......

reviews: This is more than a rags to riches story. This is the story of an incredibly smart and wonderful woman who got to be heard - yes, because her husband became president she got to be heard by a much larger venue, but I believe she would have done fabulous things without him as well.She gives me hope. She gives me reason to believe all is not lost.Read this uplifting book and begin to believe it will all be ‘great’ again.

reviews: This book chronicles Michelle Obama's life in a way that is relatable and down to earth.  I found it to be a story of the joys, trials and worries we all carry with us as parents, friends, and partners, maneuvering our way through raising kids AND keeping sane with work, friendships, family life, etc.  The only difference is this particular story is told from the perspective of a much grander scale, given her role as FLOTUS.  I was able to relate to her on all levels, as a kid growing up in a fairly tight neighborhood, with family nearby, and saddled with the angst and concerns that come to us all.  As she matured and became a wife and mother I found that her concerns were not unlike my own on a day to day basis:  keeping our children safe, giving them a good education,  hoping all the while that they will become well adjusted, productive adults.  However, she had the additional burden of keeping them humble in the face of privilege, the much bigger effort involved in remaining committed to their community, and the additional skill it took in pursuing family interests outside the oval office.  These tasks were not easy as she writes about the safety concerns and protective requirements that are part of being the first family.  But I found her anecdotes and stories to be heartfelt and truthful and am happy that she felt confident enough to share them with us.  Two thumbs up!

reviews: I could not put this treasure of a book down and am sad to have completed this rich and honest look into the first family's life. Thank you, Mrs. Obama, for sharing your truth and allowing us to be part of your journey and history. I am forever changed and guided by your words.

reviews: there's nothing to add that hasn't already been written more eloquently, but michelle obama is brilliant, entertaining, intelligent and wise. reading the book adds these qualities to my every day life and i find myself once again filled with hope.

reviews: This is an excellent well written book!  It shows what  education and hard work can accomplish regardless of your financial begining in life.  This writer perhaps was not raised with a lot of money but she had two intelligent, hard working parents who saw to it that their children were loved and taught what counted in life, respecting others and good manners!  Michelle and Barack have Class and that is something money cannot buy!She raised her two daughters with the same ethic  though now without financial worry.Michelle did not forget what was important in life and remembers her roots and  is  very proud of her upbringing.Michelle and Barack Obama are both very kind hearted and try to bring the best out of those they meet.  They are champions of the poor and downtrodden!"Becoming" is a book to be read and learned from.

reviews: I've seen peoples reviews saying it was slow or self boasting... are you expecting her to tell her whole childhood in one chapter? Self boasting... it's literally a Memoir about her self of course she's going to reflect on her achievements . Over all it's one of the better Memoirs I've read.

reviews: Mrs. Obama, I feel this time with Becoming was personal. We could easily be friends. We are so different and yet in the heart of what is important, values of love, families, friends and community we share so much. Thank you for being so personal. It matters. I wish you and your husband a wonderful future that you design together. May all who read your words hold them close as we vote in 2020 to make words matter once again. To appreciate intelligence. To respect preparation. To live without a scandal once a minute. To care about our children's future, to return to REAL values like truth, justice, equality and liberty for all. Bless you and yours.Shirley A. Blair Keller, Three Rivers, CA

reviews: I have been a huge fan of Barack Obama from the first moment I heard him. I loved his book, " The Audacity of Hope." The title alonen defines him. What I didn't know was what an extraordinary woman Michelle is. Loved every moment of this book. I believe history will one day have to admit that Barack was the best president we've ever had and undoubtedly Michelle was the best First Lady.

reviews: Well written, candid& detailed.Written in a way a layman person can relate to the events.Learnt so much about what Michelle Obama's childhood, college life, work life, love life, campaign phase and behind the scenes as First Lady.I laughed, cried, worried, then had so much hope, then laughed again as i walked through her journey.I have a soft spot for military families and she did too.Watch Becoming Michelle Obama on Netflix to learn more about her post First Lady life.So inspiring!Thank you for this gift!!

reviews: I read this book cover to cover over a weekend where I had to take two 6-hour flights. To say it is an easy read is an understatement. The style is so conversational and if your background and culture is similar to Michelle's you can definitely relate on so many levels. She was able to articulate very complex feelings in a way that made me say, 'I couldn't have said it better' or 'that's exactly how I feel'. I gifted four copies to friends and loaned my copy to my mom. Good job M.O.!

Inspirational, jaw-dropping, and mindset-shifting. This is a must read for anyone, especially young women looking for a role model and some guidance in life.

reviews: This is one of the best memoirs I have read in a long time.  It is interesting, educational, concise, funny, informative yet very readable.  It will stay with me for a long time.  It is something I never expected to read...a memoir from the first African-American first lady of the United States.  I am so glad to have had this experience...so proud.Delia

reviews: The book reminded me of a time in our nations history when Hope filled the air. Michelle Obama is a hero to so many. After I have finished her biography I more fully understand why. Her story is an amazing one and it gives anyone who has ever been viewed as “other” encouragement to persevere in the face of odds stacked against them. I finished this book in two days. My first experience with Audible. The story was enriched so much by having Michelle Obama and her rich voice tell me about her life. Everyone should read this book.

reviews: Michelle Obama has written a well chronicled events of her life that answers so many questions. It resonated with me because I could see myself and my experiences within her narrative. I cried, I laughed out loud and I cheered. It filled me with hope for the future and inspired me to take action to be the change I want to see. Thank you, Michelle, for letting us in and sharing more of yourself.

reviews: Michelle Obama's book is about much more than life in the White House, in fact, that is almost an after thought.  Thee real draw is the life of a family that did the very best they could to exemplify the American Dream - the respect and love Ms Obama shows for her parents, and they for her is a lesson in parenting.  Her relationship with President Obama has the ups and downs of an actual marriage, but with a level of sensibility and respect we could all only wish for.  It is a great read and so worth it.

reviews: I loved this book, and I continue to love Michelle Obama! I learned lots about her, her family, and what it is like to live in the White House. I laughed and I cried while reading this book. I miss the Obamas in the White House and went back to watch many of the speeches and events she tells about. It made me sad and appreciative to read about how she stretched herself to do things a FLOTUS is expected to do but was counter to who she is. I cannot recommend this book enough.

I loved every moment of this book and wish there was more.I have read her husbands book "the audacity of hope" and after reading this I was sure to get his previous book as well. She is all-around lovable and provides insight to her life and her we went from the streets to the Whitehouse.I loved this book beginning to end and tried reading it in one sitting but ended up savoring and enjoying the chapters.

reviews: She was an elegant and much loved First Lady.  The story she tells about her roots in Chicago's South Side, doubts overcome, opportunities and people that enabled the journey, the accomplishments she achieved, the work she did, the bond with the man who became our 44th President, and the challenges of being a mother, First Lady, and role model for women.  To get to know her story in her own words was intently interesting and deepened my respect and admiration of her.  It is no wonder that she is consistently voted the most admired woman in the world.

reviews: This book was a fascinating and intimate look into Michelle's life. I am going to read it a second time already because there were a number of common sense principles that she expressed so beautifully that I need to work on applying in my own life. I am white, and I appreciated learning first-hand about her experiences as a black child / young adult / woman in this country. It served to make me want to examine my own assumptions and how much I have taken for granted in my life. I learned so much from this book. It gave me hope for humanity, too.

reviews: I thought the book was well written and delved into Michelle’s childhood and experiences to where she is today.  Her and Obama made history by becoming the first African American family to be elected and live 2 terms in the White House.  Having 2 young daughter also was quite the challenge.  They overcame the predjustices  of many on both sides, black and white etc.  it was tough having security people around all the time and trying to make things as normal as possible.  They did it with grace honesty and love of country.

reviews: Outstanding story about a black female child brought up in a  rough south side neighborhood of Chicago in the 1950-1960's;  raised by her hard working parents with their own  struggles;  and to become this independent woman who had expectations of greatness for herself.  Who aspired to be whoever she wanted to be.  And then by the grace of God she met her true soul mate and together how they became the President  and Mrs. of America and  served this country with all they had become.

reviews: The great thing about this book was the seamless integration between how Michelle is hardwired and how her life is an integral part of our own lives. To say the least I'm much more enamored with the way she juxtaposed what we saw in the public sector vs how innate they are as a family. Thank you for opening up your own life and the door for others to see.

reviews: The best book I have read in such a long time. Michelle Obama's story of the south side of Chicago to the white house is a remarkable story with wonderful detail.  I lost hours of sleep because I couldn't stop reading.  Looking at Barack's election and the life in the White House was such a revealing story, the back story of what it was like to live it.  Her recall and detail and her love for her husband, children and her country shine through on every page.  Read it!

reviews: Great book!  I couldn’t put it down!  I have always admired Mr. Obama and now I admire Mrs. Obama even more!  She is an amirable wife, mother and businesswoman. It’s a shame she won’t consider public office, America will miss out on all of her strength and kindness.

reviews: I had expected a book that would focus primarily on the political life of Michelle Obama. Instead, I discovered a multi-dimensional human story.  Politics play a role, but primarily for the impact on the author's self view, her family and the social and economic causes to which she applied her considerable intelligence and energy. She is mission driven to make life better for people. Her passion for children's health and veterans employment have been a centering force for her. She also comes across as very human, something that leaps out throughout the pages.The book has an appealing tone of not pulling punches. At the same time she makes her points in a tasteful, emotionally honest manner. I look forward to her "next chapter."

reviews: This is a book everyone should read. As a family and as individuals Michelle and Barack Obama are remarkable people. The book provides insight into the challenges of being the wife of the president, it helped this old white guy understand the challenges of being brown in what is still a racist society, and it made me appreciate even more the eight years during which this remarkable couple occupied the White House.
text: This is a book everyone should read. As a family and as individuals Michelle and Barack Obama are remarkable people. The book provides insight into the challenges of being the wife of the president, it helped this old white guy understand the challenges of being brown in what is still a racist society, and it made me appreciate even more the eight years during which this remarkable couple occupied the White House.

reviews: The queen herself wrote a fine fetching book, that deftly handles the horrible dark side of America that the meer existence of the Obama family seemed to dredge up, and it shows again howc dignity, class, integrity, and faith in ones self and a higher purpose can, as they always have in the past, rise above this most recent wave of vile puerile toxicity in our society.

reviews: This is GOOD READING; not just a hum drum documentary of her life, this book reads like a story and it is so well written you will feel as though you are right there living this life with Michelle Obama. It reads like a movie; a really great story that you don't want to end, you want to just keep going to see what happens next! There are times I just can't put it down and I am so tired, I just can't fight the sleep any more. This book come highly recommended; you will enjoy it.

reviews: I enjoyed this book from beginning to end. Learning about Michelle's childhood, the people that helped shape her into the woman she is today, where she grew up, the success against the odds of the neighborhood. It was all interesting. She is so human sharing that politics was not her choice, but how she embraced it and accepted her responsibility to be a change maker. I learned a lot about her husband, how they met and how supportive they are of each other. I loved both of them before reading the book and love them even more after reading the book. Well written, easy to read and informative. Job well done Michelle Obama!

reviews: Fans of Michelle will love the book.  After reading it, I admire her even more than I did before.  Those who hate Michelle and Barack would probably not be swayed -- cannot imagine they would even read it.  Reading the reviews here, I doubt the negative reviewers actually read her book -- writing a review was probably just another opportunity to express their hate.

reviews: Michelle Obama’s book “Becoming” is beautifully written.  It is written in a way that you walk & feel her journey as you read it.  And most important you feel the realness, kindness, open heartedness, generosity, and intelligence of Mrs. Obama in every word written.  Thank you for sharing your story with us.  I hope it especially inspires young woman to see that “becoming” is more then a word but a life long process that you too can achieve.

reviews: Michelle Obama is one of the most poised and relatively woman around.  I hope this goes to required reading. In schools everywhere.  Her life as First lady should inspire everyone to be a better person.  Her legacy is one ever woman should grab on to and shout out and let your voices be heard.At a time when our leaders have no morales, are name calling bullies, all women should join together so our children and grandchildren can learn what democracy is and what it stands for instead of asking" why is it ok for our president to call people bad names and when we repeat his words are punished and told again that is bullying".

reviews: It's nothing to dislike about this book. From the first two to three pages I read I realized I couldn't put it down. Lady Michelle tells it like it was from childhood up to when she left the White House nothing held back. The book is awesome now I know why it sold so many copies. Out of all the books I've read in the past nothing can top this book. After I read my book I passed it on to a friend then went to the library and borrowed the audio. It was even better because I could relate to what I had read in the book moment by moment. Anyone who has rated this book a one, two or even three must not have read the same book I have read called "Becoming". My phenomenal First Lady!!

reviews: Thank you so very much. Michelle.....if I may call you by your first name?One of the reasons I gave your book a five star rating is because of the naturalness and vulnerable style of your writing. One of my mantras in my own recovery from addiction is "I am enough!"Also, I love that you talked a lot about raising your girls and the feelings of motherhood. I have two grown sons and they have always meant the world to me!It was refreshing to learn a bit about the everyday life of living in the White House and what that entails too.I am so glad and grateful that you and your husband were in the White House for those four years! I can't even believe how Donald Trump got elected. He is not the material I would choose for a leader of our country but obviously many people thought he was.I pray that we can get a next president with integrity and values as you and your husband had!Best to you and your family and again thank you for all you have done and for all you did as First Lady!Warmly,Peg DugganPegduggan@earthlink.net

These comments must be from those of whom are expecting the industries of the past to return.  Must be dangerously coal mining.

reviews: An honest, poignant memoir of her humble beginnings, her upbringing by her steadfast and focused parents who taught her how to dig in, overcome obstacles, reach for her dreams. It stood her in good stead. The record of her years in the White House is an insight into the behind the scenes. There is nothing really that’s new — the Michelle we saw is the woman she is. She’s strong and brave, a lion-hearted mother and wife. She’s a leader and an inspiration. I enjoyed the record of her and Barack’s early years. Michelle’s openness, leadership, dignity, compassion and clarity show why she’s one of the most admired women in the world.

reviews: I don't normally read much non-fiction, nor do I normally review books because reading likes are so personal and change. That said, I must say I thoroughly enjoyed reading "Becoming." I've always been impressed with Michelle Obama. This book puts into perspective why. I couldn't put a finger on it before but her love of her husband, girls and country shine through. Also, she has made it her lifes work to help people, and mostly girls and women, be there best selves. I was surprised at her self-doubt but impressed how she would overcome it in situations. I also enjoyed her detailing so much of her life as First Lady. A very good read.

reviews: Great insight into her own trajectory in life.  I admire her for her efforts to make life better for others. It is hard to imagine the confining life of a FLOTUS yet having exposure to wonderful as well as harrowing experiences.  It is great that she was able to transcend limitations to promote meaningful system change. And it is sad that she, and we, now have to watch the systematic attempts to destroy all that she and her husband worked so hard to accomplish. I hope this accomplished, smart, and effective lady is able to become even more effective and enjoy her life more peacefully.

reviews: Michelle Obama’s book not only served as a fascinating chronology of her life and that of her family, but more importantly a look into her and her husband’s unwavering belief in grassroots activism to lift all to new heights. Her frank discussions of racism, gun violence, and anti-feminism are notable. Her devotion to children and the education of young girls in all countries is inspiring and necessary.Clearly, Michelle Obama was a product of an incredible family, filled  with  unwavering love and guidance.

reviews: Michelle Obama has such a way with telling her story. It's as if she invited you for tea, and you're sitting across the table from her. I found her life to be entertaining, touching, and everything that a man like President Obama would find to be a perfect match to his outstanding personality. But she holds her own with such love and compassion. Never ever taking for granted the people that loved her, cherished her, and for every single person that she gave back to.

reviews: In “Becoming,” Michelle Robinson Obama shows herself to be an inspiration to young people worldwide for her intelligence, her courage, her determination and her passion for truth.  In our deeply troubled times, she calls to mind words sometimes attributed to an earlier occupant of the East Wing, Eleanor Roosevelt:  “It is better to light a candle than to curse the darkness.”  This is exactly what  Michelle Obama has done in writing “Becoming.”  The book is a beacon of light and a source of guidance to young people trying to make sense of what is currently happening in our nation and in our world.  The trajectory of young Michelle Robinson’s life is far beyond what many would have predicted for a black girl raised on Chicago’s south side, but by that very fact proves that the seeds of what we can become lie within each and every one of us.  We are not as we may be perceived by those who lack imagination, empathy and faith, but are instead kernels of possibility, waiting on the nurturing touch of others straining toward the same light, the same truth and the same promise of ‘becoming’ that inspired this excellent book.

reviews: Her book is an amazing tribute to what hard work and determination can do for a person’s life. She tells her life story with a genuine, intelligent voice. This  book should be required reading for high school students everywhere.  Hopefully, it will inspire children to do their personal best and follow their dreams.  She has been a positive force in American  History and I am grateful for her part in serving  my country.  Pay no attention to the one star reviews. I seriously doubt they even read  the whole book.  I believe she wrote this book from her heart. There are those that will not use their heart when reading it. That’s their loss.

reviews: First, I want to make clear that the one writing this review is me, Alicia Rotman, although it will appear as written by ‘guillermo rotman’ who is my husband. That is because we share the Amazon account and it’s in his name. Having said that, on to my review of Michelle Obama’s book “Becoming”…I LOVED IT! Excellent book! Couldn’t stop reading it! Thank you, Michelle, for sharing your story! And please forgive my familiarity but you have opened your life to us, the readers, and I feel I could happily be your friend. I admired you from the moment your husband was elected President and you and him and your beautiful and bright girls so graciously adapted to your role as the First Family. I admire you even more now that you have shared all the ups and downs of those intense years leading to the even more intense eight years in the White House. I think wholeheartedly that Barack and you did a great job. I congratulate you for that and wish you and your family all the best! With love and appreciation, Alicia Rotman.

reviews: You won’t really know Michelle Obama without reading her remarkable story. Born to a working couple on Chicago’s South Side, she was raised to not only be her own person, but also to inspire girls of the world to respect education as the path to equality and achievement— and to make positive change in a world that desperately needs our better angels.

Mrs. Obama is a woman of grace and dignity living in a world that has lost sight of this accomplishment.  If you don't read any other books this, READ THIS ONE.  Truly inspiring.

reviews: I have to thank my Book Club for recommending this book, as I surely would have otherwise passed it by.  Overshadowed by her brilliant husband, Michelle Obama is in her own right a remarkable overachiever.  As my Mom would say about people who had conquered their challenges, "She worked at it.".  She is not shy about criticising D. J. Trump but is so gracious about it.  So perplexing that someone could be elected who has not an ounce of grace himself.I digress.  This book is well written but not bookish.  Her warmth and compassion shine through the pages describing her journey.  A must read.

reviews: I am a white female close to my 70th birthday. I am so thankful that I bought this book. It has been full of fact and information, and the inspiration we all deserve as human beings. I recommend it for anyone interested in Chicago, Politics in General, the Years Barack Obama was our president and how to overcome adversity in all aspects of our lives. There is so much the general public doesn't realize in regards to politics and why someone chooses it as their path. And I hold a new respect for the President and his First Lady. This book is based on fact and is professionally written with love and respect for all people. I recommend it over and over again!

reviews: I chose the highest rating  because I see pieces of me and my family and people I've known in my 60 years of living.  She is me.She is me as a black woman of the same generation full of the hope that racial integration brought.  She is me as an educated woman coming from humble, very humble means, whose family sacrificed to send me to good Schools.  She is me as she developed an understanding of the special concerns of military spouses like me.  She is us.

reviews: I'd never really thought of Michelle Obama much, I mean I knew she was the first black First Lady. Reading her book, though, I really learned about her initiatives. I knew the general gist of what happened in terms of Barack Obama being elected for the first and second terms of presidency, but even though the results were expected, to be immersed into the world is a completely different experience. I laughed, and I cried, as if it was all a surprise to me, as if there was an element of suspense. I love books when it makes you consider things you almost always already knew, but never got to feel or empathise with. In this case, she made me consider how the general public was and is always so quick to make snap judgments about everything, without considering the layers of aspects going on in any one person's life. How other people lay in on Barack Obama for missing out on a vote, because their daughter had had a high fever. On closer inspection, most of us would have put our loved ones first, but no one really looks closer when it's easier to blame someone for anything. I loved this book. I felt like I could relate to Michelle Obama's story, which I think is high praise, considering I'm clearly not the first black First Lady of the United States.
text: I'd never really thought of Michelle Obama much, I mean I knew she was the first black First Lady. Reading her book, though, I really learned about her initiatives. I knew the general gist of what happened in terms of Barack Obama being elected for the first and second terms of presidency, but even though the results were expected, to be immersed into the world is a completely different experience. I laughed, and I cried, as if it was all a surprise to me, as if there was an element of suspense. I love books when it makes you consider things you almost always already knew, but never got to feel or empathise with. In this case, she made me consider how the general public was and is always so quick to make snap judgments about everything, without considering the layers of aspects going on in any one person's life. How other people lay in on Barack Obama for missing out on a vote, because their daughter had had a high fever. On closer inspection, most of us would have put our loved ones first, but no one really looks closer when it's easier to blame someone for anything. I loved this book. I felt like I could relate to Michelle Obama's story, which I think is high praise, considering I'm clearly not the first black First Lady of the United States.

reviews: I have had this book for two years and finally decided to read it.  It was like looking a lens of my very own thoughts of being and becoming a Black professional woman in America.  Mrs Obama had endured and handled herself with class and dignity. Most of all, she held on tightly to her family based foundation, never wavering from being a conscientious, beautiful, intelligent, driven woman of color who grew to understand “swerving” in life is scary but necessary.  I’m inspired and encouraged to never settle for less.  Thank you for validating - “I’m enough.”

reviews: What you see in the media does not let you into the backstory. This book took us well into Michelle's life and far enough into Barrack's life to feel as though you had a better understanding for who they truly are and what was behind their actions. I came away understanding what thoughtful and caring individuals they truly are and how much work it was for them to be good stewards of the presidency. Both of Obama's are good parents and outstanding human beings. This book just gives us the background on where that all comes from.

reviews: Michelle's narrative is rich, enlighting and shows a decent, good human being embrace life, making the  most of it. A very enjoyable journey showing a nice family, a good natured president and a compassionate, bright first lady of the USA. As a female corporate attorney myself, and former partner of one of the biggest firms in South America, though, I have  one little comment: I would  like to respectfully remind Michelle that it is  thanks to the corporate world that the ONGs may exist. That being in the corporate  businesses may be as fulfilling and good natured as being  in the public service scope. Good, conscious corporate activity creates good quality of life to millions of beings. This because  o  her insistent remark about uprising a "more fulfilling carrier" in the  public sector.

reviews: Michelle’s story has encouraged me in so many ways. As a First Lady, you have to always be the protector and not allow people thoughts to diminish you and your family. She was so transparent and her personality is so refreshing. There were times when I laughed and also cried. Her love for her husband is so sweet and their story is a true testament of Black Love. I purchased this book at a critical time in my life and it was like therapy. I accomplished my first goal, 1 book down and 3 more to go.It’s was a journey and I thank her for sharing.

reviews: As parents, and spouses, the Obamas seem almost too good to be true but I do believe!  (I hope we never find out otherwise.)  Michele's story reminds us that the American dream is not dead and that there are people who care deeply about civility and giving back.  I hope that she never, as she has often said, runs for office because I'd hate to see someone of her character be subject to the muck that exemplifies our current political situation.She is an excellent writer and a clear and expressive narrator.  Brava!

reviews: *Becoming* is a comprehensive, well-spoken memoir of life in progress fully experienced. The heart of our former (mine always!) FLOTUS feels life’s ups and downs every bit as fully as her well-educated mind rationalizes them.Even in recounting the cloudiest moments of her life, and of our nation’s, Mrs. Obama retains a twinkle of encouragement for her reader. Perhaps this tiny glimmer holds significant reason for her book’s wildfire popularity: its ever-expanding readership is savoring a positivity that we sorely need now more than ever.

reviews: For someone like me who is not American this biography was most interesting. I have not experienced racism and all I know about it is what I have read in books. I was compelled to read again "Dreams of my father" by Barak Obama as I thought the two stories complemented each other especially in their differences. Michelle Obama is an example of a true African American and what can be achieved in spite of the racism and the fact of being a woman, with hard work, resilience and perseverance while Barak Obama needed first to find his true identity, a much more complex one. But because of this complexity I think he was able as a President to embrace the whole nation and serve it to the best of his ability even if he was unable to achieve all his goals since the Congress was so much against him and often obstructed his decisions just because he was black. These are the stories of a formidable couple which history will not forget.

reviews: And I have read a lot, as a 75+ woman, retired professor, and political junky, mother, grandmother, and professional. I cannot recommend this more highly. I could not put it down. Michelle has opened her life and soul in a way few do, or could. And there is so much to be learned by those of us who never had to walk in her shoes. Historic and Awesome!

reviews: As an avid reader, I challenge all my friends and family to put aside your differences and carefully, with an open mind and heart read  ‘Becoming’ , from the very beginning to the very end.

reviews: Michelle Obama is so real and warm in this book, letting all of us feel into her heart and mind. I will miss reading her writing, and forever miss the style, intelligence and dignity she brought to The White House. She and her husband will always be my favorite leaders. I am a descendant of the Hairston Clan, working my way through reconciliation of having been the largest slave holders in the country. Michelle and Barack gave me tremendous courage, to lift myself out of the shame and celebrate all that is possible, in a world where power is balanced through equality and addressing racism openly. I recommend this book to anyone who wants to dive deep into the real truth of this amazing first family, and come to a clear understanding of the backlash and horror that ensued when they left.

reviews: When I heard Mrs. Obama was going to write a memoir about her life, I knew at once that I was going to read it. I was excited to read the details of how she and President Obama met and fell in love,  what it was like being a busy working mother of two on multiple campaign trails, the intricate details of living in the White House and how the first family executed their 8 years in office with grace and dignity.Politics aside, this family is an inspiration, Mrs. Obama is an inspiration. I cried when she told the story of the only time the President needed her during the work day, and I laughed when she talked about their girls antics on the campaign trail. I was inspired to expand my own home garden after reading about the garden Mrs. Obama had built on the White House lawn, and will strive to make sure my children have healthier options as they grow.Some of the things she wrote about shocked me, like the federal funding for redecorating for each new first family, or all that is actually included in the presidential motorcade. I have a new respect for all past, present and future Presidents and their families - they really do have the hardest job in the world.The worst part about this book was the end; the fact that it had to end. I wish I had known some of this information while the Obama's were in office and I wish they could have more time. I'm grateful for all they did for our country while they were in office and I wish them all the best for the future.

reviews: I do not want my description of Michelle Obama "Amazing" to seem trite.  I mean that word in every sense.  Mrs. Obama  was raised to be a great, achieving woman.  She excelled in so many areas.  Mrs. Obama walked beside President Barack Obama with grace, such wisdom and determination to help him achieve the status of being one of our greatest presidents!  I thank God for her.  I thank God for all that she has become.

reviews: I loved this book.  I have been telling everyone I know about it.  It keeps you interested.  It isn't showy it is about a real person that had and still has the love of the people of the United States.  She took her place in being the first lady as an honor.  She sounded proud in this book to represent all of us wherever in the world she had to go and speak.  She stayed humble because that's how she was raised.  It made me feel like she was my best friend just the way the book was written.  I am glad I decided to get it.  I hated when I was done reading it.

reviews: To start I want to say that I NEVER write reviews for books, or anything really, but this book was so good I could not hold my thoughts to myself. Michelle writes candidly, in a moving way - the book reads almost like a novel it is so well written. She lets readers into the depths of her life before, during and after the White House. She shares truths that will resonate with so many people, both women and men and brings light to the (still) ongoing prejudiced society we live in, without making anyone feel alienated. The book is raw, but positive and will give you hope for the future of America and your own life, even in this current period we are in. Bravo Michelle, BRAVO.

reviews: Michelle Obama’s story is a true rags to riches tale.  The influence her parents played in her life path is something that should be emulated.  When given love and support as a young person, anything is possible.  Extrodinary is the coming together of Michelle and Barrack.  Together they accomplished what may not have been done individually.  A story to read to recover hope in our society and know that anything is possible with a belief in self and a plan forward.

reviews: Entertaining, profound, inspiring and beautifully written. I listened to her read it and followed along in the book so I could highlight the parts that spoke to me deeply. Loved her authenticity in sharing her story so far (she's still Becoming)...the joys, pains, lessons and victories. It was all great but Becoming Me was truly my favorite part. I laughed heartily and shed quite a few tears. Also, the insight into politics, life in the bubble and service from the vantage point and perspective of the FLOTUS and First Family, and this particular family, was interesting and enlightening. I loved it all!

reviews: The book was like having a conversation with an old friend. It was an easy read, and it was entertaining, not entirely gossipy and classy. It was simple read that talked about the First Lady's upbringing, college education, marriage to President Obama, family life and the eventual move to the White House. It differed from her husband's writing style in the sense that Michelle Obama is relatable, and her book is easier to read.  I loved it.

reviews: Really great book. If you want to be great you need to study the greats. I would recommend reading this with children too.

reviews: I loved this story about how Michelle Robinson grew up in south Chicago and blossomed under the influence of her loving family and community members. She shares her experiences of education from her elementary years thru her college years, and how she becomes aware of disparities in her world. Her mother's guiding principles and her father's work ethic, even though he lives with a debilitating disability, instill solid morals and confidence to believe that anything is attainable in this world. After she becomes Michelle Obama, she gracefully, although hesitantly boards the political train that takes her to the White House. Learn about her journey and how fortunate we are to have her and her family in our lives and in our world during this time.

reviews: OMG! I did not want to finish it - wanted to hold on to how I was feeling as i read it! I found the book to be an honest (sometimes brutally), intimate and loving look into her life. She spoke of her values & beliefs and her philosophy about marriage, child rearing and family. Was so interesting to read about her life from the time she was born in "South Side Chicago" right up until when the Obamas left the White House. There were times I was moved to tears when she described some touching and painful things she has seen and / or experienced. Read it in a day - could not put it down!

I wrapped up the Epilogue once again invigorated and hopeful about the innate character and resilience of our country and the residents within.

reviews: You’re giving a glimpse into how she became the First Lady and the struggles with her husband wanting to run for a political office. I loved this is her story about how she got here. There was no self pity. She is a strong, beautiful, courageous woman that’s provided grace as the first African-American First Lady. It explains so much.

reviews: I found myself reading this and feeling again the sense of loss and mourning of the Obama’s leaving the White House. I so miss their gracious and thoughtful approach to leading our nation. Michelle embodies that and reflects that as much as ever in this book. She gives a personal look at the path that led her to the White House, including giving a very human perspective on the doubts and challenges that came with all the privileges of the Obama’s lives while there. She also shares valuable reminders and encouragement about the power in using your voice to stand up for yourself and to continue to strive for change - both living in the world we are in today and working to make it the world we want. A reminder that was refreshing and helpful to hear with all the division that feels ever present today. And of course, she includes a friendly reminder that every vote counts. Just in case you forgot.

reviews: Becoming is a very well-written account of Michelle Obama’s life. She is so honest about her feelings, challenges and triumphs that I felt as though I was living them along with her. While much of the history is well-known, she provides an in-depth look into growing up black in Chicago’s South Side and what that experience looked and felt like for a bright, ambitious young woman. Her honesty about the challenges of a political life is frank and moving. I highly recommend this book!

reviews: This memoir is so nicely constructed and well written that it's a pleasure to read.  Michelle Obama's journey from Southside Chicago to the White House is endlessly interesting.  Hers is a very human story and she portrays it touchingly and eloquently.  It was hard reading this book and thinking of what came after her husband's presidency but the hope that drove those eight years is not dead, despite all the efforts to dash the accomplishments of the Obama administration.  Reading "Becoming" will warm readers' hearts and bring the occasional tear to the eye.

reviews: A good read...especially for women.  MB discussed the challenges of managing a career and family with a spouse that had an equally, and obviously more demanding, career.  Yet, although she shared moments she felt she could have done better, she is confident she did the best she could.  No apologies...and that’s good for women to hear.  It didn’t male bash or female promote...MB wrote a clear book about her walk and decisions and thoughts.

reviews: Well-written, inspirational, and exciting. One of the more fast-paced memoirs I’ve read. I loved the stories of her childhood and glimpses inside the White House, and any mother can relate to the challenges she faced as a working mother. I’m pretty sure that the one-star reviews are from Red Hats who never even opened this book!

reviews: I enjoyed getting to know the Obamas through the eyes of Michelle.  She and Barack grew throughout their lives and seemingly continue to grow as people.  Michelle spoke openly about their respective weaknesses, strengths, mistakes and triumphs. She's the kind of person anyone would enjoy having as a friend and/or neighbor.

Each"Becoming"  carries you through  the progressive stages that took her from being a little girl to becoming the First Lady.  Excellent writing and easy to read because it keeps It  you moving through each  phase.  I think you'll enjoy it as I did.

reviews: Everything and everyone has other, and sometimes not so secret, agendas; yet Mrs Obama managed to write a wonderfully light recount of her experience, managing to create such a light setting that it's easy to forget she was living in the White House, falling asleep next to the most powerful man on earth.Is everything true? Was her life such a normal, even unassuming, series of events until that election?I honestly don't care. The story is wonderfully written, alternating moments of stress and tension to everyday accidents (the ones with the Queen made me burst into honest laughing), and that's what I liked the most: no matter how powerful and entwined this woman became, she managed to write her story without ever becoming judgemental or biased. And that's what I take with me after finishing her book:  a sense of equilibrium, of higher values, of unbiased good concepts that don't need labels to be relatable.

reviews: It's Michelle Obama. What's not to like about a tags to riches story. Beautiful, supportive family. Hard working true Americans. Never a hint of scandal. Classy family. Her book seems like raw HONESTY. If she can ... others can too!!!

reviews: I eagerly awaited Michele Obama's autobiography, "Becoming", and it did not disappoint. The book was divided into 3 sections; her time growing up in Chicago, college and early years of working and marriage, and the years in the White House. Each section was candidly written in a very interesting style. I recommend this book to everyone who appreciated all the beneficial work she did for our country. Even more, I recommend it to all young people because it gives one an idea of what is possible in life with hard work and determination!

reviews: I binge read this book during the Impeachment trial. Reading the warm, open narrative of Mrs. Obama was a shelter from the lies and ugliness in the larger world. I still have a sense of dread of what is yet to come, but also the notion that the America that was described in this book is more hopeful than hateful, and eventually righteousness will prevail.  I now want to experience it again as an audio book.  If you still carry hope, Becoming will inspire you.

reviews: I am sure there are plenty of things left out that we don't need to know, but Michelle pretty much told it like it was. It surely wasn't all wonderful. No one who hasn't been there could possibly imagine what life is really like in the spotlight. This book makes her real, and I think even more amazing.

reviews: Love the book but two copies I bought gave random blank pages. What up with that amazon?I’m terms of the book it was fantastic. I loved seeing a story similar to my own in such a well reveared woman. She is quite candid in her revelations in a way that really reflects many of our lived experiences. I find much of the criticism to be related to those truths which is unfortunate given she didn’t have to be so honest. It’s her story it boggles my mind that people would read and autobiography and be offended that it’s revelatory of the authors true feelings. If you want to know more about who she is as a woman then read this book. If you dislike her or feel that she owes it to you to frame her life in a way that’s palatable to you then you should skip it. Being First Lady isn’t easy especially when you’re criticized for literally any little thing. Some of the criticism here is a continuation of that (black folks should never be anything but happy and grateful especially successful ones so goes several of the criticisms here *eye roll*). A kind smart family woman who offered years of service and has no major scandals and folks still want to find fault lol. Anyway this book is everything for those of us who can relate. If you think you will it’s worth a read for sure.

reviews: This is really Michelle Obama's autobiography.  Naturally there is information about the president, but no more than necessary to complete her story.  I was surprised to learn that she has little interest in politics, and agreed to the run for president because she thought he would lose.  She was honest about the difficulty in becoming pregnant, the hard times while he was in the state senate in Springfield while she was in Chicago, and many unfortunate experiences while in the White House, such as the refusal of congress to even consider bills he presented.

reviews: From beginning to end, I found this a compelling book.  I really knew very little about Michelle Obama's life.  Her descriptions of growing up in Chicago, her schooling so informative and moving. She kept herself out of the spotlight as First Lady.  I understand why but felt somehow cheated that I was so unaware of what she accomplished and the agendas she and her staff moved forward.  We are all in a better place due to those initiatives.

reviews: I’ve always been a fan of the Obamas. However, after reading this enlightened story, I’m a bigger fan now! The book was extremely “real”, showcasing the fears and processes the family went through. The dignity and integrity all of they showed, even with the power they held, is what makes them a favorite. I wish we had more families like them overseeing democracy.

reviews: WARNING:  Check your book immediately.  My copy was terribly defective but I didn't realize it until I was ready to read it months later.  There were 8 completely blank pages (missing text) in the first 93 pages.  There were also several barely legible pages where the ink is very faint.  Amazon refused to replace it.  It was published by Crown Publishing Group - New York.The first 51 pages of "Becoming" were well-written and very interesting.  I plan on purchasing another copy through a different bookseller.

reviews: I enjoyed reading about the White House years more than the childhood years. But it was all good. Great insight into the background of both Obama's. I'd recommend it to anyone, of any party. I look at Michelle in a different way now when I see her on television clips. She is not arm candy. She has substance, intelligence, and she has a sense of humor that makes her so human. Michelle, I wish you'd run!

reviews: Michelle Obama's book was written so that the reader felt as if he/she were having a conversation with the First Lady.  As I read the book, I could hear her voice as she shared her experiences and feelings as a young child through her time upon leaving the White House.  The book gave the reader first hand knowledge of being part of a campaign, being a First Lady and living through the eight years at the White House.  I really enjoyed the insights she shared.  Thank you, Ms. Obama

reviews: This was a great book! I already liked Michelle Obama, however, I had no idea of her truly humble roots or how hard she worked to get where she was. I have so much respect for her heart of service, her opening her life story up and sharing it with everyone publicly after being exposed to so much hurt and criticize. It is raw and a neat look at the first family and yet so sad that to be in that place you almost have to be entirely sequestered from life.

reviews: Powerful telling of the life story from a woman who worked hard to succeed academically, personally and professionally.  Mrs Obama is an example of strength and courage, especially for girls and young women trying to figure out how to become who they want to be versus meeting the expectations of others.

reviews: This is the story of a very self-driven woman. Michelle Obama was very fortunate to have the parents and family support. She acknowledges this continually and how it is a driving force in her desire to build that support for others.  In reading this book there are so many incidents reported that I remember but had not heard the full story or known the context from which it was taken.I don't think many realize the burden she felt for her children being raised in the public eye. In spite of all the advantages that were there, she knew the sacrifices that were made. I think she tells her story well and is very positive on most incidents. The very most negative is Donald Trump's constant insistence that Barack is not a citizen. No one can put blame on her when she said if something had happened to her children, she would never have forgiven him.

reviews: I was not a huge supporter of the Obama family, but I have always enjoyed biographies. This one didn't disappoint and, in fact, gave me perspective into the back story of family who never really set out for the journey they took. It definitely becomes political at the end, but Michelle Obama speaks from her heart and holds nothing back.

reviews: I could not put this book down. This is not a stuffy political biography. I felt like I really got to know Michelle Obama, and I appreciate her perspective as a woman of color. The first half of the book is mostly about her background and the second half focuses more on her life amist politics and life in the White House. I appreciate and admire the Obama family even more than I already did. I highly recommend reading this book.

reviews: Nothing was handed to either President or Mrs. Obama.  They worked hard, kept the faith, and sacrificed a great deal to serve our country.  This is a most wonderful inspiring story.  If only hate-filled people would take the time to read and listen and learn about others, maybe they could learn to love again.  America was better when the Obamas were in the White House, because of the love they had growing up, and the love they had for one another, for people of all backgrounds, and for our country.  Thank you Michelle Obama for sharing your story!

reviews: To be frank, it's been a rough few years for my progressive values and liberal heart. It's been painful to see the progress that was made toward more balanced women's and human rights, toward racism and cultural diversification, representation and respect to be systematically and deliberately undone. I've often wondered how the Obamas could stand it. Now I know, because Michelle's voice tells me herself. If she can maintain her faith, then I can certainly try harder to find mine again."Becoming" is a book beautifully written. Mrs Obama- Michelle- generously unfurles her personal story of the journey we all take, from the childhood discovery of our strengths and cringing awareness of weaknesses to the formation of our adult sense of self. It's a story for women and the men who love them, whether husbands, fathers, sons or brothers. It's a story for white women like me to recognize the many commonalities but unique challenges our sisters of color face so that we can be allies and not "others" to them. I'm grateful to have been invited into Michelle's South Side Chicago upbringing. I hope millions will take the open door and find much to empathize with in her story. The ability to empathize is surely God's greatest gift to the human race. If anything can save us from destroying ourselves, it will be empathy.I want to believe I'll see a better America come back in my lifetime (I'm 59). Reading the words of this woman of great integrity, intelligence and action, who has seen the best we can be firsthand and helped, with her remarkable husband, break barriers and pave new roads forward, is just what I've needed to gird myself for the year to come. I hope another leader will rise from the current cesspool to pull us forward again.

reviews: To start off with:  I love Michelle Obama.  In this book, her childhood, education and experiences are told with honesty and a strong message of, "If I can do this, you can!"  She admits her fears and insecurities and details how she overcame them to grow in her personhood and her spirit.  Well written, honest, inspiring.

reviews: Michelle Obama tells all! The first half seemed to drag on with a few embarassing moments of TMI, but plow through and it all comes together for an intriguing look at how this remarkable woman, against her own life desires, learned to balance work, family and politics  while turning her passions into projects having widespread impact, yet managing to remain true to herself. To the author I only have one thing to say: Thank you!

reviews: Michele Obama has written an intimate look into her life as a black woman growing up in the city of Chicago with the help of a caring and loving family, working hard at school and making the incredible achievement of a Princeton undergraduate and the Harvard Law School education. In meeting her husband, she describes the ups and downs of being in a relationship with a politician: being a public figure, raising daughters and working out how to find herself and how to be true to herself in private as well as in public. I found the book to be a riveting, personal story.

I didn't know too much about Michelle Obama before this book, and after finishing it, I feel like we've been friends my whole life. It doesn't matter what your political affiliation is, she's human and so relatable.

reviews: I love this woman!  At 76, I've seen a lot f first ladies, and Michelle Obama will always be my first pick.....truly a class act.

reviews: Michelle Obama's story would have been interesting as merely the POV of a woman married to a man who became president but this is so much more.  Her struggles to balance family life and work life resonate with any woman who has had to do so as well.  She is candid about her struggles to reconcile the frequently-absent husband from her vision of how marriage should be.  An amazing story by an amazing woman.  And this is coming from someone who really doesn't like autobiographies.
